I bought this in 2015 as a gift for my mom. She liked it at first, good enough for her basic needs, but then the unit started having an issue. It would shut off suddenly, even just after being charged. I got her a new, didn't tablet and kept this one to troubleshoot. While sitting on my desk (not in use, turned off)  the battery exploded. Beware!

I powered the tablet on and loaded all my favorite apps onto it. The tablet was extremely slow and unresponsive. I did a factory reset immediately wondering if I was throwing too much at this cheap budget tablet. Upon factory reset I just installed two apps. Facebook and the Kindle app. Facebook takes 5 minutes to open. Literally 5 minutes! And when the app loads it's slow and unresponsive. The Kindle app runs the same way.

The bottom line is this particular tablet is worthless. What good is it if you can't do anything?

It is amazing

Pros:

Snappy feeling response times for basic apps, browsing, and video
High screen resolution, for the size
SD Card Compatibility allows for cheap and easy storage upgrade
Decently powerful external speaker

Cons:

Cheap body construction
Sub-par cameras
Too little RAM for some more demanding games (EG the poorly-optimized later episodes of Minecraft Story Mode)
Some Initial bloatware onboard (which can easily be removed by a knowledgeable Android user)

Bottom Line:

An excellent buy for the money IF you're not setting unreasonably high expectations.  Particularly nice as a gift for a young child who will mostly use it to play small mobile games.  You will need to upscale to better hardware for adults, or older younglings however.

Although I have an Android phone, this is first use of Android tablet.  There are some differences to get used to, but overall, very pleased with this product.  The screen size is large enough to be easily read, but small enough to be easy to handle.  The display is crisp and the processor seems to be very fast especially compared to the Windows 7 netbook I have been using for browsing.  The only problem noted is that the sensitivity of the sound when a key is pressed is inconsistent--sometimes a character is entered on the screen with no sound, and other times the sound is present each time the screen is touched.  There may be an adjustment for this, but I haven't found it yet.  I think this device is going to be very suitable for its intended use.

I had this tablet for only a month before it shut off, never to turn on again. This was a month of only casual Clash of Clans playing (and literally nothing else), so naturally I requested a replacement. First the representative had me try some "solutions" to try to get it working, but eventually sent me the info for return. Upon receipt of the replacement tablet I found I could not even set up the tablet because half the touchscreen would not work. I tried resetting factory settings and wiping the cache partition which did not solve the issue. Going back once again to the Dragon Touch representative, they wanted me to send the serial number printed on the back of the tablet so they could send software to fix the issue. Only problem is this tablet (and the previous one) did not have the serial number printed on the back, I'm assuming from some additional oversight at the Dragon Touch warehouse. I have lost all faith in this product. It's got some bang for the buck. The processor's pretty quick, although apps take a while to start. Once they *are* started, my games are running nice and smooth. I thought the placement of the mini-usb port was awkward at first, but it's in a good place to get a finger under it while holding the tablet in portrait orientation. The plastic case seems sturdy enough; it's certainly lighter than other tablets I've used. An hdmi port and a flash on the rear camera would have been nice, but I can get by without them. Can't say it's a five, but it's pretty good for the price.

For the price it's an ok tablet. It does what I expected it to do and that's stream movies from my computer. I haven't tried Hulu or Amazon video yet, but my network's pretty fast, so I should be ok. The screen came with a protective film already installed besides the one with instructions printed on it, I ditched is as it wasn't as responsive as I liked, with it removed it responds most of the time, but not 100% of the time. That's to be expected in this price point from a rather unknown brand. The screen resolution is ok, nothing to get excited about. Movies look good, but the color can look washed out depending on the viewing angle. Left to right is ok, up and down is where the color washes out. The built in speaker is ok, but plan on using headphones or external speakers if you plan on playing music or watching video. The front and rear cameras are crap, but I hadn't planned on using either of them. If you're on a budget and really want a tablet, then this class would be ok for most people. I on the other hand plan on getting a better tablet with more RAM and memory as this has 512MB RAM and 8GB storage with the system taking a huge chunk. It also has a micoSD card slot which supports 32GB of additional storage for movies, music, pictures or other files you wish to store.

I could also look at notes and powerpoint presentations for my various classes as well as keep a schedule/to do list on the tablet. I just had those two or three simple things in mind. That is what I planned on doing.

However, I have not turned on this tablet in months.

It isn't that this tablet wasn't able to do any of what I expected. It's that the interface is garbage and the tablet is super slow.
The touch screen was very unresponsive. I kept having to smash my fingers into the screen to click into anything. The web browsing isn't very fluid and is very clunky.
The tablet is very slow. I spent around 5-10 minutes trying to load a power point presentation on the tablet.
PDFs are the same was. Many times when I scroll, the tablet just won't respond.

The is basically a large phone, except a lot slower.
I wish I had not bought it.

First off, I would like to say that you should not get drawn to a tablet for the price! Everyone really wants "as low as you can go" tablets these days. Also the speed of it and internet made this tablet more worthless than a tablet of advil.
Pros: NA
Cons:
1. Brightness. I tried putting it on the highest setting, but that made it WORSE. My old iphone 2g has better brightness that this piece of crap from a junkyard. I bought this so I could use it at the park or on my front porch, but the screen went black. I had to go in my closet to do anything.
2. The loading speed. After I booted up the system, (which took 5 minutes) I went straight to the play store to download snapchat (lame, right?) After 10 minutes, the app downloaded, I opened it and it took 30 seconds to load, which was a major improvement, compared to the internet speed, but we'll get to that later. Snapchat actually worked OK.
3. The Internet speed. I searched up " weather" on my junkpiece, and this thing would refuse to load right next to the WiFi router! My brother is a brainy at technology, so I asked him what was up. First thing he said was to always buy name-brand tech. Boy, did I learn my lesson. He couldn't fix it, and, for the record, this is an adult that is going to Marquette next year as an engineer.
I want to just say, that if you are considering buying this tablet, go with a kindle fire instead. To find it, just search it in the Amazon search box.

Even if it's inexpensive, you still want it to work.  I like the size, visibility, etc, but the device is not useful because it freezes up constantly and has to be rebooted several times a day.  It doesn't seem to matter what the application is, it will freeze up with Facebook, games, news sites, you name it.  It takes many times longer to do anything with the tablet than my desktop because of the freezing issue.  Also, it has relatively low memory and I'm frequently uninstalling apps to make room for new files.  Camera resolution is the lowest I've had since my very first digital camera in the late 1990s and even though it takes panorama shots, you have to move so slowly, they are very poor quality.  Streaming is ok given a strong wifi signal.  If you get this, be sure to get a screen guard too, as the glass scratches very easily.

I bought this as an inexpensive replacement for two much more expensive tablets my dog destroyed. Maybe this would be a good choice for someone who has never used a tablet or smart phone, but experienced users will find the slow response and lag time extremely frustrating. When I bought this, I did not expect this to measure up to my previous tablets by any means. I simply wanted an affordable device to watch Netflix, read email and read/post on Facebook. That's it. Accessing apps can take a minute or more, often nothing happens at all. Posting even a short email or Facebook comment can take 2-3 minutes as you wait for the app to respond, but Netflix works well with this tablet. Using a good memory booster app helps a lot. I gave this three instead of two stars because the screen quality is quite good - crisp picture with nice color - as is the sound quality. If you just want to watch movies, this tablet will be fine. If you want to do anything else, upgrade.

I initially bought this tablet because the value was phenomenal. 50 dollars for a machine with clear picture and reliable speed. I thought it would make a great and affordable gift for a young relative. Functionally, the tablet does all it claims to do, however, the first tablet I bought quickly succumbed to a faulty power button. The tablet could not be turned on or off manually by the power button after approximately 3 months.

Customer service was mildly adequate, however, the only solution they gave me for the problem was pay for repairs. The repair would cost me approximately 30 dollars. 20 dollars shy of a new tablet. I assume with a price so low that is the nature of the beast, but the tablet only experienced approximately 3 months of use. I was surprised to find out that there was nothing else the company could  do to make it right.

Nonetheless, I figured  i figured that I had just received a lemon and this was sheer happenstance. I purchased another one to replace the broken one. At this value, I was certain that it would not break the bank and that my nephew would be more conscientious about taking care of it. After 4 months, the same issue occurred. The power button failed to activate the tablet.

It was unresponsive and unusable. This issue occurred twice. I paid 100 dollars for two tablets that barely had the durability to last a year. This isn't right. Customer service was never really able to make it right. I can't support this product, and I don't think people should buy it.

Notes: The tablet was always in a protective casing, and while it experienced heavy use, the screen barely had a scratch on it. The tablet was well taken care of, but its durability lacked integrity.

Anyone making a purchase for this unit should manage expectations. Overall it works well for most basic tasks but it might not suit every person or every need. This is my main goal with a device such as this and this tablet specifically. I want to be able to... Surf the web occasionally Check my emails Adjust me thermostat (when as home) Run Torque Pro Playback music/movies occasionally (mostly YouTube) View WiFi cameras Screencasting (It has the option, MIGHT use it MAYBE) I don't need it to play games, none will ever be installed. I have used the MicroSD as well as an OTG cable and both work fine and allow me to view text, pics and video without issue. It's not the fastest out there but for the price it meets my needs. It includes a charger or you can use MicroUSB to charge so if you happen to want to use the MicroUSB AND charge you can leave the OTG cable plugged in (as an example). Images look nice, sound isn't bad at all but of course the cameras aren't going to be the best but they're fairly decent. My only real complaint is the battery life is on the low side. You should charge as suggested in the manual (10 hours first two times then 7 hours after that). I do not need any tablet to run for very long...about 2 hours max at one time so this lasts well beyond that and does well in standby...lasts most if not all day but depends on what I leave running of course. To sum this up...if like me you only need pretty basic use then for just under $50 bucks this works but if you think you're going to multi-task and run any game you would be wrong. For me it is good but my advice is to manage your expectations and shop accordingly. I would not own this as my only or main tablet but as a spare for what I listed above it is just fine. Adding more memory would go a long way to make this a more well liked product. Review sample provided free or at a discounted price for a fair, unbiased, and honest review.

The materials of the casing itself are normal plastic and look like something you find on dubious products from a flea market. It advertises an IPS display, but its specs do not allow the device to fully take advantage of that.

The quad core processors don't really provide any punch. It's not all that surprising, considering it's a $4 processor. So, considering that, it's a fair deal. The RAM is sufficient for small tasks, but I really don't think I can use this tablet for anything, but development (for low-end devices). Potentially, the newer model would be a better deal, but this is definitely an entry-level tablet that gives a good deal for what's being offered.

The stats on the tablet can be found in the description section under the actual product on amazon.com, so I am not exactly sure what else to add....but what I can say is that:

1: The battery life was really long-lasting initially....but after only 2 months of using this tablet, the battery life doesn't last longer than 3-4 hours, within a 24/hr time frame. My kids do not use this tablet every day all day, so I was disappointed to see the battery life decrease so soon on these tablets.

2. The Camera: The camera is the equivalent of built-in webcam, from a cheap laptop...nothing fancy. The picture quality is not horrible, but it's not great either. You can see your photos, but you can also see the unclarity/pixel used to create the photos...if that makes sense.

We are a graywater systems manufacturer, using android tablets as the 'brain' of our IrriGRAY 16 zone graywater / rainwater / condensate / potable water irrigation system.

Chinese tablets have been a constant source of frustration for us, because all winner / softwinner tablets almost always have malware / adware on them.

The Dragon Touch Y88X Plus tablet is the first allwinner architecture tablet, based on our testing and also discussions with TabletExpress, that really is clear of bad pre-loaded software.

The A33 based quadcore tablet is a big jump ahead of dual core tablets - larger memory, 4 times speed performance with our system, much better battery and power consumption.

We now buy in bulk, however when we see a good seller, with a very good product, we like to spread the word. This is an unsolicited testimonial and we are not claiming the free gift for this testimonial.

For those who have complained about bubbles on the screen - when the the packing cover is removed from the screen, there is still a screen protector in place. This can be lifted carefully and refitted, or removed. For every day use I suggest leaving it in place.

Paul James
Water ReNu LLC
Plano Texas.

I had this Tablet for a month now and found some problems. (Got it on January 28, this review has been edited on February 27)

The Dragon Touch Y88X Plus is a fun tablet, it's a great deal if you're looking for a low budget tablet and Googleplay provides with ton of apps, so the fun can keep going.

Performance: If you're just looking for a tablet for reading this one is ok. Some apps that demand more power were pretty slow to load, games like Galaxy of Heroes and Marvel Academy sometimes freezes for 10 seconds on the loading screen, other games closed itself if it's too much for the tablet to handle (like Pocket Mortys)

Camera: The back camera is ok, it's like a camera from a phone from 2009, but when using it for apps the camera would be upside down and rotating it would just set off the auto-rotate for the screen (I heard this could be fixed, but I didn't invest time into the camera part of the tablet). The front camera is just horrible, I have it set on auto adjust, but everything is just orange if I do that.

Battery Life: When playing a game it would take about 3 hours for it to get to 5% from 100%. When you're just using it for everyday use, it takes about 5 hours. I used this on the bus and it's an hour trip bus, usually when I get on the bus it's 100% and when I get off the bus it's 80-90%.

Charger: The charger is a HUGE downer for me. The plug to the tablet is loose and wobbly. As of today (February 27), it doesn't charge my tablet if my tablet is faced up on the table. It's kinda like some old Sega Genesis consoles where you have to position it just right for the plug to turn the console on.
I read some reviews saying the charger doesn't hold a charge and how other chargers bought from Amazon doesn't work, but the charger from my old tablet works fine.

Durability:It feels like it would break if you drop it, but that's to be expected with the cost, I highly recommend getting a case.

SD Card: The tablet takes a MicroSD card, Google doesn't allow putting apps on the SD cards now, but that isn't really the tablet's fault (Just letting everyone know, this is not going to affect my rating for the tablet)
If you want extra storage for movies, books, and music then an SD card is a good way to get that extra storage. The Largest the tablet could read is 32GB.

Storage: 8GB isn't much in this day and age, but gotta remember this is a 50 dollar tablet.
For 8GB I ran out of space from all the apps I downloaded and I had to remove a lot for extra room. (This wouldn't be a big deal if Google allowed you to move apps to SD cards like before)

Longevity: I will update this if my tablet breaks or if it's still alive 5 months from now.

(This review will be updated once I have more experience with the tablet)

I got two of these for my 4 and 6 year old kids to use.  I figured I would find a third party app and use it as parental control.

About a week after Christmas, and my kids repeatedly telling me that they keep restarting on their own, I decided to factory reset, drain the battery, etc.  They worked well for a bit, but then started some quirky antics.  Needless to say, they're only $50, so you can't expect they're going to be perfect.  The biggest downer is the fact that there is so much preinstalled software on here, and it randomly pops up while my kids are trying to use them.  They have no idea what it is or what to do.  They just press every button they can, and now they're in danger of downloading other stuff, bringing their tablet to me, and saying "daddy, its doing it again".
Fast forward a month and a half now, and I finally gave up on my sons tablet.  All he wanted to do was listen to music and play angry birds.  The restarting and freezing was out of control.  I basically took his tablet and told him I'd get him a new one.  I did a bit of research, and really feel I found the best option FOR LESS MONEY!  I got a 7" Kindle for him, with offers, which brought the price down.  Then I happened to get it on sale.  THEN, I looked up how to get the Google Play store on it (which doesn't require any "rooting", just following simple directions, and a one time PC use).  The kindle is much more solid, never freezes, has better battery life, and , best of all, NO POPUPS OR RANDOM SOFTWARE!.
I'm now going to purchase another one for my daughter, knowing hers will eventually die.
I did contact dragon touch, and they had me check a bunch of things, and then offered to take it back and either fix or send me a new one.  I'd pay for shipping, which I'm sure would be minimal, maybe $5 or so.  But I've decided to just cut my losses.  I know the product is inferior, and I learned my lesson.  The company seems like they're doing their best to help out, but the  product itself is something I wish I never purchased in the first place.

The company told me to "charge" it then hold the power for 20 secs. Yeaaa......here in lies the problem: I have no charger that works people! I was contacting the company to order a new charger directly (didn't see it on their website). Yet, all I'm told is that parts warranty ends at 90 days, returns and exchanges up to 30 days after purchase. I'm told everything but whether or not I can order a new charger. Do yourself a favor, spend a few extra bucks on something better!

Moves right along with games, movies/videos, presentations, social apps and everything else I use. 8GB may not seem like a lot of space out of the box, but if like me you find 8GB might be a bit limiting, the addition of an Micro-SD card is adding additional space via the micro-SD card slot on this tablet. In terms of accessories, the tablet has just the basics, Dragon Touch 7" tablet, USB cable, Wall charger. Really all I could need right out of the box.
Overall, a really great budget tablet for spec's and performance. The Dragon Touch Y88X Plus 7'' Quad Core Tablet is a great bet when screen size and connectivity is a must. I will recommend it fellow co-workers.

I bought this as a replacement for my small-but-clunky laptop, which is painfully slow and is surprisingly much of a hassle to travel with because the power cord block is large, heavy, and oddly shaped.  I also didn't want to replace my cell phone with a smart phone and have to pay for an expensive data plan.  So - I got this tablet instead, and I'm delighted with it.

Pros:  It's small, easy to carry, and its power cord block is slim and light, like the ones that come with a cell phone.  It's faster than the laptop, the screen is bright and sharp, and it has available apps for everything I want to do when I'm away from home.  Securing it with a password is easy.  Kindle books look beautiful with on it (there's a Kindle app).  Keeping up with email is a snap.  I thought I would have trouble surfing the web because of the small screen (I use a 20" flat screen with my desktop), but I adapted pretty quickly.  I like that there is a slot for a microSDHC card.  It also has Bluetooth.

Cons:  I still find typing on a touch screen tricky because there is no tactile feedback, but at least I don't hate it as much as on the last device I used (an old Kindle).  Battery life is not that great when online - and Pandora seems to use it up pretty quickly - but email and games can be downloaded and reviewed/played with in Airplane Mode, which uses very little battery life.  The speaker are VERY tinny.  I'll try earphones.

Bottom line:  Does all I expected of it and more.

My 5-6 year old Kindle Fire doesn't hold a charge any longer, so I figured I'd upgrade to something modern.  This had a much faster quad core processor, and reviews were decent, so...

Performance is disappointing.  The limited amount of RAM I think keeps it from being a real contender.  Running more than one application at a time is generally pretty sluggish, and you know the CPU is more than capable.  Even Candy Crush slows down, what the heck?  Once the application is loaded into memory everything runs fine.  My company provides an LG G3 phone which totally blows this away in terms of performance.  Again, more RAM...

As for build quality, I was prepared for a cheaper feel but even still I was surprised.  Having been used to the aforementioned LG, Kindle Fire, and various iPads, I was still blown away how cheap and plasticy this felt.  Not a deal breaker for me, but if you like that solid, brushed aluminum feel you should look elsewhere.

The screen is decent, exactly what I expected.  For general use I wouldn't let negative comments about the screen dissuade you.

The biggest annoyance is that the unit has a non-USB charging cable.  Why?!?  I have a fleet of micro-USB charged devices, and now I have to have a separate one for this?  It will charge from USB, but very, very slowly.

Anyway, for single tasking activities this is OK.  Personally I would have preferred to save my 50 bucks and put it towards something better.  It's a good value, and would do great for someone who wanted to hand a tablet to their child and not worry about they losing it.  Or for backpacking across Europe  this would be a good internet device you wouldn't cry over if stolen.  It has its place, but it's definitely not a premium tablet.

The power button does not even work,  it's flush with the casing instead of raised like the other buttons you can press and it also has scratches on the back of the case.  Overall I feel like it's money wasted,  now I'm out a tablet,  and have a very upset little Boy.

Music
--------------------------
Needless to say, the tiny rear speaker is  absolutely poor in sound quality, but it is also quiet, next to inaudible outdoors walking down the street. As someone who listens to music with headphones this isn't an issue, So imagine my surprise when I plug in my headphones (Audio Technica m50x) and discover that the sound coming from my headphones were poor quality aswell. If I had to judge, the sound caps out at the lower end of 50mhz, absolutely ZERO sub bass. The sound is tiny, spiky, and just plain boring. I wanted a simple tablet to listen to music with, this isn't the tablet for that. Music lovers beware.

Multitasking
-------------------
No. Just, no. The quad core processor in this is good enough to handle multitasking but the device is throttled by that pathetic 0.5 gig of ram. Dragon Touch shot themselves in the foot by supplying this device with such an unacceptably small amount of ram.

Gaming
---------------
It can play casual games just fine. As far as Higher end games go. It absolutely FAILS in this category. Real Racing 3 on low settings with no other applications running in background was as I expected, Choppy with extreme frame rate loss. I wouldn't have bothered including higher end games in the review had the device not allude to it being gaming capable by advertising it being "3d game ready".

Camera
-----------------
Again, as I expected, Not good either. Video and camera shot in native 4:3 ratio with no settings to adjust the picture. Video quality I estimate films at around 15 frames a second at around the quality of a youtube video at 240p. Sound quality of capture also wasn't too great either.

Display
----------------
Not HD, Pixels are visible even when sitting away from device. Don't let the advertising fool you.

Durability
---------------
Everything from the body to the screen is thin plastic. A child could snap this tablet in half. Very flimsy. I'm not too confident in this devices build quality.

Overall.
---------------
As I said before, it is what it is. It's a cheap tablet. Though in today's world where most phones run at around 2 gigs (4 times the amount) of ram and most applications require more ram now then ever. It's easy to break, so I cant even recommend giving this to a child as a cheap toy, the sound is bad, the camera is bad, and my over all experience with this device is well, bad.

This tablet is just too under powered for today's world, and has left me to figure out what to do with a 50 dollar paper weight. Don't let the price seduce you into buying it. Just save up and buy something better.

The Dragon Touch Y88X Plus is a fun tablet, it's a great deal if you're looking for a low budget tablet and Googleplay provides with ton of apps, so the fun can keep going.

Performance: It has opened smoothly and played every app I have downloaded. Only complaint I have is some games had stuttering (the newer games that require more power).

Camera: The camera doesn't really stand out for me, it's a pretty low to medium end camera.

Battery Life: When playing a game it would take about 2 hours for it to get to 5% from 100%. When you're just using it for everyday use, it takes about 6 hours.

Durability:It feels like it would break if you drop it, but that's to be expected with the cost, I highly recommend getting a case.

Longevity: I will update this if my tablet breaks or if it's still alive 5 months from now.

Dragon Touch Y88X Plus 7'' Quad Core Google Android 4.4 KitKat Tablet PC, IPS Display, HD Screen 1024 x 600, 8 GB, Bluetooth, Dual Camera, Netflix, Skype, 3D Game Supported - Graphite Black Hello all, this is actually my very first time owning a tablet, due to the fact my notebook is screwed but that's for another time and day. And was very happy that it didn't take long getting delivered! Okay this is the start of the review. Well it starts like this, listen when you open the box, it comes with 1 USB cable (the USB cable doesn't charge the device) also comes with D/C power charger that plugs into the wall, but if you love USB like i do, there is a possibiltiy that you could just buy a USB Sync/Charging cable from somewhere else. Because I've heard people going into panic mode because the tablet will not charge with the USB cable. The performance is incredible. I just love the Quad Core processor that's running at 1.2GHZ (on the box it says 1.3GHZ, but when i loaded up everything it stated that i had 1.2GHZ QC) Let me explain something to you guys about the battery, i know many of you kind of worry why the battery dies so fast. Below are the causes. Running, multiple apps Bluetooth enabled WIFI (Only if you just want to sit around and play a game without accessing the internet) Screen Brightness Levels... (You should be fine with the default screen brightness) Spotify (eventually if you are listening to music for a long period of time, it kill your battery life) Also, running Spotify and launching apps at the sametime such as Google etcetera. If you we're wondering about setting it up for the first time with your name and other personal data. You'll have to download apps on to the tablet because the tablet doesn't come with pre-loaded goodies. Also make sure you enable WIFI once you set the system up, when i purcahsed mine i had to enable WIFI in order to surf the web, just mentioning incase you all may not know about this just helping everyone out! If you are wondering abou the screen, It's a pretty decent screen, it's very responsive, i had another android device made like a sony psp, and it was junk, you cant to press so hard on the screen just to get it working... And anyways, if you guys are wondering if this gives out HD, sorry to tell you but the tablet isn't in High-Def, the native screen resolution is 1024x600, but it has beautiful rich vibrant colors when looking at beautiful places like Brazil, Dubai and here home in america! But if i we're you I'd buy the tablet it's great for everyhting without slow down, as long as you kill the apps running in the background you should be just fine. Because all the traffic that's going into your tablet. PROS: Speedy quick 1.2GHz quad core processor Great for playing video games, as long you are in a wifi area Price I do believe I've paid 60 dollars for it and a lovely screen protector Great performance in most games, never had hicup yet.. CONS: The Volume Rocker, it gets confusing for me depends on how i am holding my tablet gets annoying sometimes, Headset Jack It's not really a "CON" but i dislike the fact that i sit the tablet in my lap the plug from the headphone jack pokes me... Camera, well i don't expect the camera to be fantasic, but the quality is very low, but i must say that my iPhone 3Gs, has a better camera Also by the way I've added some photos of my tablet, i did it so you know what you are getting. Enjoy hope i helped some of you all

I had previously noted some of the positive features associated with these relatively inexpensive tablets, but after running into problems I decided to revise my review.  The screen stopped working correctly on one of our tablets after about 6 months of light use.  The screen filled with horizontal lines that blurred any displayed contents.  No problem, right?  The product has a 1 year limited warranty, so getting a repair or replacement shouldn't be a big issue.

Wrong.

When I contacted the seller (AKASO Store) about the warranty, they quoted me a price of around $30 to repair the tablet.  When I asked about the 1 year warranty, they replied that they do indeed have a 1 year warranty, but that it's not a "free warranty."  Anything beyond 3 months requires the buyer to pay for warranty services!  Calling a paid repair service a warranty is deceptive and unethical.  Don't be fooled by this product's misleading warranty promises.

Came with pre-installed malware, otherwise okay tablet. The malware noticeably started to act up weeks after purchase, it would download unwanted apps, specifically:
'Ten Drops' and 'Likin Hero' by Foxx Games
'Insane Stars' by Jun Li
'Special Recorder' whose icon looked like the default speech recorder icon, but purple.
'Services' whose icon was a red exclamation point in front and to the right of a green fan shape which just led to the wireless & networks screen.

The malware would remove the antivirus/scanner when connected to the internet.

The two malware processes were the following:
Troj.cloudsota.z in com.android.popup
Android. MALWARE.at_cloud.b in GoogleCalenderPluginService

As for the tablet itself,
It feels flimsy, although it isn't.
When transferring files to a computer, it would occasionally restart.
With some .gifs, the picture viewer quits after one loop.
The wireless network scanner is slow to detect -any- changes, such as a new network appearing or the current network being disconnected.
The screen can be jumpy, and when new its very coarse.
It can't handle many simultaneous apps , as it would often restart or lag with plenty of ram available.

But still an okay tablet, for $50.

I purchased three of these for my nephews and niece for Christmas.  They arrived a few days ago, and I took them out of the packaging to make sure all of them worked.  First off, even after plugging these in and letting them charge, one of the three didn't hold a charge at all.  The other two had their batteries drain off the charger in less than an hour with nothing running.  The power buttons on 2 of the 3 you could hold for 5 or 6 minutes before the device powered on.  The date/time zone wouldn't save.  They keep reverting to central time, and use a 24-hour clock even when you uncheck that option.  The KitKat 4.4 OS also doesn't update. AT ALL.  Finally, these tablets are *cheap*, flimsy plastic that actually bends in the hands of adult with very little force applied.  I can't imagine this product in the hands of a 5, 8 and 10 year old.  They'd be busted before Christmas Day was over.  I'm returning all three and buying Kindle Fires.  Lesson to me -- you get what you pay for.  I wanted to make sure the kids had an Android device to get access to the PlayStore, but these tablets aren't worth what it will cost to return them, let alone the cost of the actual device. (Edited to add, one of the most annoying things about these tablets is that the charger is a push in/plug adapter and not a standard USB/sync cable.  You can't charge these tablets with anything but the cord they came with, and getting the pin connector in so you hear it snap into place is not something your child can easily accomplish. Please keep that in mind)

I have about 200 kindle books.  The tablet starts to freeze after loading the first 20 cover images from my library.  Trying to use chrome even with one tab was pretty much too much for it to handle. It was also really flaky and there was a lot of lag so you would end up clicking on the wrong option even if a button wasn't actually there at the time.

We have been using this tablet for our son to watch movies in the car. After the first couple of weeks it became very difficult to charge. It takes several hours just to go from say, 30% to 50%. and the battery life runs out very fast. We went with the cheaper version because its for a child, so we don't expect it to last for ever but still. It shouldn't take so long to charge it. With that said, the only other issue we have(which is a big one)is that it continuously drops wifi connection while he is at home streaming you tube for kids. Other than those two issues, it plays movies with decent resolution and doesn't lag like I have seen from other reviews. I hope this information helps other shoppers.
